awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Smart & Connected Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site engages students in research in the emerging area of Smart & Connected Communities (S&CC), the essential building blocks of smart cities. Through a nationwide recruitment process, cohorts of 10 undergraduate students will participate in a 10-week summer research program, for three summers, hosted at Texas State University. Special efforts are made to recruit students from primarily teaching universities and colleges while ensuring the participation of women, veterans, and minorities. The project includes mentoring by experienced computer science faculty members, technical seminars and workshops, student presentations, and professional development opportunities. These activities are carried out in an intellectual environment that develops the students' professional careers through enhancing their technical, communication, and social skills.

The research component in this REU Site falls along three main thrusts in building the next generation of information and communication technologies supporting the development of S&CC: (1) models, mechanisms and tools for smart human-environment interactions to monitor and protect smart infrastructure against accidental failures and malicious attacks; (2) new methods for collecting and analyzing various types of data ranging from human biosignals to activity and crowd-sourcing data, to promote health and well-being of citizens in urban settings; and (3) novel scheduling and monitoring methods for intelligent transportation systems that would decrease congestion, promote safety and reduce adverse environmental impacts in urban settings. Evaluation of the proposed methods is done through theoretical and numerical analysis, simulation experiments, and real implementations with various devices, sensors, and robots.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report for NSF REU Site on Smart & Connected Communities

The NSF-funded REU Site on Smart & Connected Communities (S&CC) at Texas State University has involved 38 undergraduate students and eight faculty mentors in research aimed at enhancing smart and connected community technologies. This initiative focused on creating scalable, secure, and efficient solutions across multiple domains, including intelligent transportation, smart infrastructure, health and well-being, and human-environment interactions. The program offered a comprehensive educational and research experience, encompassing theoretical foundations and hands-on development with cutting-edge technologies.

Intellectual Merit

The project's intellectual contributions are multifaceted, encompassing the development of models, mechanisms, and tools designed to improve human-environment interactions, data analysis for urban health and safety, and novel approaches to intelligent transportation systems. Through rigorous theoretical and empirical research, participants have contributed to the advancement of knowledge in S&CC domains. Notable outcomes include:

  • Publications in peer-reviewed venues, addressing topics from understanding social anxiety to multi-camera vessel activity recognition and protection of cyber-physical infrastructure.
  • Presentations at major conferences, including strategies for autonomous refueling in smart cities, fall detection systems, and text analysis for understanding social anxiety symptoms in student veterans.
  • The development of open-source software packages, such as a semi-supervised labeling tool for time series data, enhancing the research community's resources.

Broader Impacts

The REU site's broader impacts are evident in its support for undergraduate research, professional development, and dissemination of findings to a wide audience. The program has:

  • Enhanced the research skills of 38 undergraduates, encouraging them to pursue further studies and careers in research. 33 of the students were funded by this grant, and five more students who participated in the site's activities were funded by other NSF grants.
  • Promoted S&CC education through demonstration and poster sessions, contributing to the broader knowledge base in transportation, infrastructure, and healthcare.
  • Disseminated outcomes through various platforms, including the REU site's website, peer-reviewed papers, student articles, and presentations at professional meetings.

Participants received comprehensive training in research methods, ethics, presentation skills, and paper writing, along with exposure to graduate school opportunities. Participants were also brought in contact with leading industry companies through in-person field trips and online meetings with IBM Austin, Google Austin Southwest Research Institute (SwRI), San Antonio, and Emerson Austin. Research findings were disseminated beyond academic circles, reaching the general public through posts on the REU site, publications in public forums like Medium.com, and source codes in public repositories.
